column3: Description
I can evaluate a limit graphically or numerically including one-sided and infinite limits. (Section 2.2, 4.6)
I can evaluate a limit analytically (using algebra), including one-sided and infinite limits. (Section 2.3, 4.6)
I can recognize points at which a function is (and is not) continuous and can use continuity to evaluate limits. (Section 2.4)
I can identify limits in indeterminate form and can apply L'Hopital's rule correctly. (Section 4.8)
I can understand the limit definition of the derivative and calculate the derivative at a point. (Section 3.1)

I can calculate and interpret instantaneous rates of change at a point using graphs and tables, and I can understand the difference between the instantaneous rate of change and the average rate of change. (Section 3.1, 3.2)
I can sketch the derivative function from the graph of a given function (specifically f' from f).  (Section 3.2)
I can find the tangent line to a function at a given point. (Section 3.1)
I can use the Product and Quotient Rules to compute derivatives of simple algebraic, trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions in combination. (Section 3.3,3.5,3.9)
I can use the Chain Rule to compute derivatives of simple algebraic, trigonometric,exponential, and logarithmic functions in combination. (Section 3.6)

I can use a combination of the Product, Quotient, and Chain Rules to compute derivatives of simple algebraic, trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions in combination. (Sections 3.5, 3.6, 3.9)
I can compute derivatives correctly using implicit differentiation. (Section 3.8)
I can correctly interpret the meaning of a derivative in context (e.g. velocity, acceleration). (Section 3.4)
I can use calculus to find local and absolute extrema of functions. (Section 4.3 & Section 4.5 )
I can explain the relationship between a function and its first and second derivatives (concavity, increasing/decreasing, points of inflection). (Section 4.5)
I can apply the First Derivative Test and Second Derivative Test to locate local extrema.  (Section 4.5)
I can solve related rates problems.  (Section 4.1)
I can use anti-differentiation to solve initial-value problems. (Section 4.10)
I can evaluate definite integrals exactly by using the properties of definite integrals, graphs and geometry. (Section 5.2)
I can estimate the values of definite integrals numerically using the left-hand sum or the right-hand sum. (Section 5.1)
I can evaluate definite integrals exactly by using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (FTC) part 2 with an antiderivative.  (Section 5.3)
I can interpret the physical meaning of a definite integral in terms of net area, net change, displacement, or distance, and state its units.  (Section 5.4)
I can evaluate integrals using the Substitution Rule using definite and indefinite integrals.  (Section 5.5 and 5.6)
